title: 107_s1535
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Melanie Stokes Postpartum Depression Research and Care Act". Postpartum depression is a mood disorder that affects many women during and after pregnancy. It can be categorized into three subgroups: "baby blues," postpartum mood and anxiety disorders, and postpartum psychosis. "Baby blues" is characterized by mood swings, tearfulness, irritability, poor sleep, and vulnerability. Postpartum mood and anxiety disorders include symptoms like worsening baby blues, affecting 10-20% of new mothers. Postpartum psychosis symptoms involve losing touch with reality, paranoia, and rapid speech, striking 1 in 1,000 new mothers. Over 400,000 women experience postpartum mood changes annually, with baby blues affecting up to 80% of new mothers. The causes of postpartum depression are complex and unknown, possibly linked to hormone level changes after childbirth. Postpartum depression can be caused by various factors such as hormone level changes after childbirth, lack of support, marital strife, stressful life events, and personal history of depression or anxiety. It is a treatable disorder that requires prompt diagnosis and personalized care including social support, therapy, medication, and sometimes hospitalization. Unfortunately, postpartum depression often goes undiagnosed. Postpartum depression often goes undiagnosed or untreated due to social stigma, the myth of motherhood, inability to self-diagnose, shame, lack of understanding, and economic pressures. Untreated, it can lead to further depression, substance abuse, loss of employment, divorce, social alienation, self-destructive behavior, or suicide, impacting society through the infant's physical and psychological well-being. Child abuse, neglect, or death of the infant or siblings can have a significant impact on the infant's physical and psychological development, as well as disrupt the family. SEC. 101. CONSENSUS RESEARCH CONFERENCE AND PLAN CONCERNING POSTPARTUM DEPRESSION AND PSYCHOSIS. Amendments are made to the Public Health Service Act regarding research on postpartum depression and psychosis. The Secretary, in collaboration with federal agencies, will organize national meetings to develop a research plan for postpartum depression and psychosis. This plan will include basic research on causes and epidemiological studies. The research plan for postpartum depression and psychosis includes epidemiological studies, improved diagnostic techniques, clinical research for new treatments, information and education programs for healthcare professionals and the public, and a plan for dissemination of information. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the research plan for postpartum depression and psychosis within 2 years of enactment. After developing the research plan, the Secretary will expand research activities through the NIH Director, focusing on postpartum depression and psychosis. A report on these efforts must be submitted within 1 year. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress annually on the progress of the research plan for postpartum depression and psychosis at the Nation Institutes of Health. TITLE II--DELIVERY OF SERVICES REGARDING POSTPARTUM DEPRESSION AND PSYCHOSIS

SEC. 201. DELIVERY OF SERVICES REGARDING POSTPARTUM DEPRESSION AND PSYCHOSIS. Subpart 3 of part B of title V of the Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a program of grants for services related to postpartum depression and psychosis. The Secretary will provide grants for projects to deliver essential services to individuals with postpartum conditions and their families. Grants can be given to public or nonprofit entities, including hospitals, community organizations, and health centers. The projects will focus on effective and cost-efficient systems for postpartum care. The Secretary will ensure that projects provide services for the diagnosis and management of postpartum conditions. Authorized activities may include outpatient and home-based health services, inpatient care management, and improving the quality and availability of healthcare services. The program provides services for individuals with postpartum conditions and their families, including attendant care, homemaker services, day or respite care, counseling on financial assistance and insurance. The Secretary will integrate the program with other grant programs. "SEC. 520L. CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS." "A grant under section 520K requires the applicant to agree to use no more than 5% for administrative purposes, supplement not supplant other funds, follow limitations on charges set by the Secretary, and not use the grant for services already covered under section 520K(a)." The applicant receiving a grant under section 520K must use funds for authorized services, with payment expected from state compensation, insurance, or health programs. They must also post notices about federal policies on charges for services provided. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to help entities comply with chapter requirements to be eligible for grants under section 520K. Authorization of appropriations is available for fiscal years 2002 through 2004.
